724670f-a.text:
West Street, Spring, to Charlton Street.(Before Reconstruction).

President Borough of Manhattan.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE.                       June 9, 1918.
724670f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

723399f.text:
353 and 351 Spring Street, at and adjoning the N.E. corner of West Street. The corner building store is occupied by the Savannah Lunch and Rest. Roane Bros. occupy No. 351. These structures, including No. 349 which is not shown were demolished in 1927. This photograph is taken during work on the West Street sewer project, concurrent with the Holland Tunnel boring.
May 3, 1924
Standard Photographic Service
Gift of Borough President of Manhattan
723399f.folder: Spring Street & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724665f-a.text:
West Steer, North West corner and Spring Steer, showing the site of the Savannah Hotel.

June 14th, 1924

Standard Photographic Service

724668f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724664f-a.text:
West Street, north from and including Spring Street and Pier 35, North River. The West Side Elevated Highway is under construction from this point north to 23rd Street and Eleventh Avenue, it will
be opened in November.
The boy on horseback is supposed to be warning vehicles and pedestrians out of the way of the oncoming train.
June 3, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
724664f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724669f-a.text:
West Street, west side, from Spring to Charlton Streets (Piers 36-37, N.R.), showing city officials, led by Borough President Julius Miller, making an inspection trip up the first section of the West Side Elevated Highway from the southern end. The first section extends from Canal Street (actually from the western end of Spring Street) to 23rd Street. Ground was broken by Mayor Walker and Borough President Miller on May 24, 1929; and the section will be formally opened on
November 13, 1930.
October 27, 1930.
International News Photos, Inc.
724669f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724681f-a.text:
New Freight Terminal Dedicated
The New York Central's New St. Johns Park freight terminal on Spring street on the west side of New Your City, was formally dedicated June 28th with officials of the State, city and railroads present no exercises. The new freight terminal is part of the railroad's West side improvement project. Above is a view of the tracks on "Death Avenue" (Eleventh Avenue), taken from the north side of the terminal. The new development eliminates part of the dangers of "Death Avenue"
6/28/1934
724681f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724682f-a.text:
New Freight Terminal Dedicated
The New York Central's New St. Johns Park freight terminal on Spring street on the west side of New Your City, was formally dedicated June 28th with officials of the State, city and railroads present at the exercises. The new freight terminal is part of the railroad's West side improvement project. The next step is the reconstruction of the yards at west 30th st. The above photo shows the special train carrying dignitaries officials and engineers as it entered the new terminal for the ceremonies.
6/28/1934
724682f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724683f-a.text:
New Freight Terminal Dedicated.
The New York Central's New St. John's Park Freight
Terminal in Spring Street on the West Side of New
York City, was formally dedicated June 28th with
officials of the state, city and railroad present at
the exercises. The new freight terminal is part
of the railroad's West Side improvement project.
The above photo shows eight tracks entering St. John's
Park terminal with present facilities for about 150
cars. Rolling steel doors at entrance are guarded
by red and green signal lights. This building occupies
three city blocks at present, and will later be extended
four hundred feet, making it with the extension and the
addition of nine stories more in height one of the largest buildings in the world.
CREDIT LINE (ACME)  6/28/34
724683f-a.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

723398f-a.text:
Demolition of 353-349 Spring Street, three six-story tenement houses
at and adjoining the N.E. corner of West Street.
October 25, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
723398f-a.folder: Spring Street & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724663f.text:
(1)
West Street, center and east side, north from and including
Spring Street (opposite Pier 35, North River).
September 27, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, nearly seven years later, not including Spring Street. The Sobol filling station, which is only partly shown at the right, occupies the site of the buildings at and adjoining the north corner of Spring Street. The West Side Elevated Highway was opened from this point to 23rd Street late in 1930; and the new St. John's Park Freight Terminal, from Charlton to Clarkson Streets, is practically completed as
shown.
June 15, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
724663f.folder: West Street & Spring Street, Manhattan, NY

724666f-b.text:
(1)
West Street, at and adjoining the north corner of Spring Street, opposite Pier 35, North River. The gasoline station occupies the site of 353-349 Spring Street and 303, 304 West Street,
which have been demolished since 1927.
March 6, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same scene four years later. In the background may be seen the large, white Standard Statistics Building on Hudson Street, built in 1930, when the rest of the West Street buildings, up to Clarkson Street (Pier 40) were demolished.
June 3, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
